headline.main: Dusting Off a Serene Jewel Box

docs.snippet: Chinese and American conservators are restoring a mothballed Qing Dynasty retreat in the Forbidden City.

multimedia.caption: Long Forgotten in the Forbidden City
multimedia.credit: After decades of neglect, the Juanqinzhai is the first part of the 18th-century Palace of Tranquillity and Longevity to be restored.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: After decades of neglect, the Juanqinzhai is the first part of the 18th-century Palace of Tranquillity and Longevity to be restored.
legacy.MultimediaHeadline1: Long Forgotten in the Forbidden City

docs.lead_paragraph: Like any sensible adult, the Emperor Qianlong planned ahead for his retirement. A compulsive poet who oversaw the unprecedented expansion of China's borders, Qianlong began creating a refuge in 1771, at 61, for his golden years. Unlike his predecessors, who ruled until death or disability, Qianlong, the fifth emperor of the Qing Dynasty, vowed to abdicate at 85 and settle down in comparatively modest quarters carved out of the Forbidden City, the imperial behemoth with hundreds of rooms that anchors the Chinese capital.

headline.main: Fire Ravages Renowned Building in Beijing

docs.snippet: A fierce blaze started by an illegal fireworks show engulfed one of the Chinese capital’s most architecturally celebrated modern buildings on Monday.

byline.original: By ANDREW JACOBS; Edward Wong contributed reporting from Beijing, and Graham Bowley from New York

multimedia.caption: Fire Ravages Beijing Building
multimedia.credit: Fire consumed a building in Beijing that formed part of Central China Television's new headquarters as residents set off fireworks throughout the city to celebrate the Lantern Festival on Monday evening.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Fire consumed a building in Beijing that formed part of Central China Television's new headquarters as residents set off fireworks throughout the city to celebrate the Lantern Festival on Monday evening.

docs.lead_paragraph: A fierce blaze started by an illegal fireworks show engulfed one of the Chinese capital's most architecturally celebrated modern buildings on Monday, the last day of festivities for the Lunar New Year, the official Xinhua News Agency reported Tuesday. The fire was not extinguished until early Tuesday morning. Xinhua, quoting a fire official, said a fireworks company had been hired to ignite several hundred large firecrackers in an open space outside the building, the Mandarin Oriental Hotel, which was under construction.

headline.main: Chinese TV Network Apologizes for Fire

docs.snippet: China Central Television’s employees defied the police by staging illegal pyrotechnics near the building that caught fire on Monday, leaving a firefighter dead.

byline.original: By ANDREW JACOBS; Huang Yuanxi contributed research

multimedia.caption: Fireworks Spark Beijing Blaze
multimedia.credit: A fireworks show on the final day of celebrations marking the Lunar New Year sparked a fire at the landmark China Central Television headquarters complex in Beijing.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: A fireworks show on the final day of celebrations marking the Lunar New Year sparked a fire at the landmark China Central Television headquarters complex in Beijing.

docs.lead_paragraph: China's national television network on Tuesday blamed an illegal fireworks display by its employees for igniting a blaze that destroyed a futuristic luxury hotel and theater here. In a statement posted on its Web site, the network, China Central Television, said the illegal pyrotechnics on Monday, the final night of the Lunar New Year celebrations, were staged too close to the unfinished Mandarin Oriental Hotel, which is part of the network's headquarters complex. The network apologized for ''the severe damage the fire caused to the country's property.''

headline.main: At Reading In Beijing, Noted Writer Is Stabbed

docs.snippet: Xu Lai, a writer known for provocative, antiestablishment Web postings, was stabbed and wounded during a book reading on Saturday.

byline.original: By ANDREW JACOBS; Jonathan Ansfield contributed reporting, and Huang Yuanxi contributed research

docs.lead_paragraph: A prominent Chinese writer known for provocative, antiestablishment Web postings was stabbed and wounded during a book reading on Saturday. The writer, Xu Lai, a newspaper reporter, novelist and blogger whose satirical Internet postings are widely followed by students, journalists and the Chinese literati, may have been singled out for his writings, his friends and associates said.

headline.main: Museum In China Lends Art To Taiwan Counterpart

docs.snippet: The Palace Museum in Beijing has agreed to lend artworks to the National Palace Museum in Taipei for a special exhibition this year.

byline.original: By KEITH BRADSHER; Compiled by BEN SISARIO

docs.lead_paragraph: The Palace Museum in Beijing has agreed to lend artworks to the National Palace Museum in Taipei for a special exhibition this year, temporarily reuniting a small part of China's immense imperial collection for the first time in 60 years, both museums said on Monday. A spokesman for the Palace Museum in Beijing said that no agreement had been reached on how many would travel. The Taiwan museum plans to borrow the works, mainly paintings, for a three-month exhibition starting in October of art from the reign of Emperor Yongzheng, who ruled from 1723 to 1735. In meetings over the weekend in Beijing the directors of the museums agreed to coordinate their catalogs and Web sites, according to the Taiwan museum, but the two sides did not address mainland China's legal claim to full ownership of the entire imperial collection, which has long been divided by strife. The Nationalists took nearly a quarter of it when they lost China's civil war to the Communists in 1949 and retreated to Taiwan. The Taipei museum refuses to lend any works to the mainland for fear that they will not be returned and has only rarely lent works from the imperial collection to other countries for fear of legal action.

headline.main: Facing Counterfeiting Crackdown, Beijing Vendors Fight Back

docs.snippet: Tenacious vendors have staged protests against lawyers who are pursuing trademark cases, mocking them as bourgeois puppets of foreigners.
docs.lead_paragraph: Any tourist who has stepped foot in this city's famous Silk Street Market can testify that it is home to some of the wiliest, most tenacious vendors who ever tried to palm off a fake handbag on a na√Øve foreigner. So when the market managers temporarily shut down 29 stalls over the past month for selling counterfeit goods, no one expected the merchants to acquiesce quietly to the loss of business.

headline.main: Built Online, Shelter For Homeless Fills Up

docs.snippet: South of Tiananmen Square, mazelike neighborhoods are being bulldozed and grand shopping promenades erected, but homeless people keep resurfacing.
docs.lead_paragraph: South of Tiananmen Square, mazelike neighborhoods are being bulldozed and grand shopping promenades erected, but homeless people keep resurfacing. Hundreds roam the area, most of them migrants from the countryside, whose chances of escaping their predicament have dimmed with the faltering economy. Many of the migrants are elderly or disabled people who came here after their relatives left their villages in search of jobs along the coast. Others are petitioning for redress for a host of alleged wrongs, including the seizure of land for development.
